# In A New York Minute

### Prolog

Carl wasn't like other designers, like interior decorators or
landscapers.  They can create spaces, but they can't create space. An
acre of land is just an acre of land. There's no steam shovel that can
turn one acre into two. Space can be marked up and decorated, but it
can't be created.

For a designer, it came down to choices. You can have the walnut
boudoir or maybe the stainless Parsons table.  You pick the one that
feels right, that creates the mood, that works efficiently, that
creates the space.

Carl didn't work with space, he worked with time. He designed
timelines. Some timelines were drab, unremarkable. People want their
time to feel well-spent. They can't have any more of it, but they do
want more from the time they have.

"More" without getting any more, that's what they get from a good
timeline designer. The first meeting is where they lay out their
expectations. They've heard stories, they bring their own dreams, they
see how others look back on what they have done. A client's time is
precious to them, and they wanted it arranged as well as it could be.

Business was good. Some clients were difficult but Carl always did his
best, even if he felt annoyed. He had learned that his first
impression wasn't always accurate, that he should be patient and wait
to see if the client was really going to be implacable. 

Space is subjective, but time is relative. A day lasts for a day, no
matter how it feels.

### chapter 1

The hotel was in good shape, not fancy but not shabby either.
It was early in the afternoon, and Carl needed to get up to
room 314 to meet his next client. He was feeling a bit tired,
there were too many things on his mind, and he just wanted to
get this over with.

There was a crowd of kids, probably some kind of high school
volleyball team, standing in front of the elevator.  They had just
arrived with their luggage. The kids laughed and elbowed each other
about some joke they shared.

It might be easier, Carl thought to himself, to avoid the elevator for
now.  Scanning the lobby, he saw what looked like a sign pointing to
the stairs opposite the front desk, behind a large philodendron. It
was only two flights up.

Nah, better to catch a ride. He waited patiently for the elevator to
fill up with kids, and let them go onward and upward. He basked in the
silence, refreshing him like a breeze of fresh air. After a few
minutes, the doors dinged open and he stepped in.
